aDGFRx-y6.memHandModelNotes: Freshwater type was selected for this species, but since no water buffers are selected, the salinity is not affected. Map units alone serve to limit this species' model to freshwater habitats.  I therefore un-selected water type from the drop-down menu above. MJR 29aug07.

habitat_description:
Historically, this species had an extensive Gulf Coast range that included west Florida and Alabama to extreme east Louisiana. Disjunct populations occurred in central and southeast Louisiana (Conant and Collins 1991). More specifically, the dusky gopher frog is an endemic to Saint Tammany, Washington, and Tangipahoa parishes in the coastal plain of Louisiana. In Mississippi, it occurs in the Hancock, Jackson, Harrison, and Pearl River Counties. They were also present in southwestern Alabama and up to 1967 in Louisiana (Lannoo 2005). Current breeding populations are known only from Glen’s Pond, found in DeSoto National Forest in Harrison County, Mississippi (Richter et al. 2003). Due to severe declines recently, reported populations are only found in Louisiana, Alabama, and Mississippi (IUCN 2015).

Breeding habitat is generally shallow ephemeral ponds that are characterized by subemergent and emergent vegetation, and floating, decaying woody litter (Lannoo 2005). Seasonal non-breeding habitat includes upland and flatland longleaf pine forests with open canopies (Dundee and Rossman 1989).
